comment._content: that's The Gentleman!

comment.author: 99646216@N00
comment._content: Chanel was a fashion house in 1928, but I doubt if anyone in those days wore trade marks as jewellery, especially princesses! They appear to be full circles anyway, not letter Cs. Nice try, heh.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/hockadilly] Oh, well! Just thought I'd throw it out there for discussion...  ;)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 99646216@N00
comment._content: I absolutely love the way you invite discussion on the photos! Makes them so interesting to look at ... I wouldn't have even noticed the brooch if you hadn't pointed it out.

comment.author: 38197978@N02
comment._content:
Yes, I never before had made a connection between fashionistas and military insignia buffs. ;)

The varieties of body language are also interesting, the Princess relaxed but aware of the camera, and the officer at some form of Attention, but also conversational, and relaxed.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/hockadilly] Thank you for the lovely compliment! I never cease to be amazed at what other people spot in the photos that I've completely missed - it's fun, isn't it?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 79903783@N03
comment._content: The Princess Royal also visited the South where she and her husband stayed in Galway (Connemara?) in I think 1928 on holidays. To the surprise of many they received a warm welcome, travelling around by car. They also lunched with the Governor General and his wife in the Viceregal Lodge.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79903783@N03] You're dead right! Apparently they stayed in Portumna Castle, though it looked as if the castle bore the brunt of some unhappiness at their visit...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
